Searching for highly active oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) catalysts is a challenging task in the development of clean energy devices. Herein, by using the poly[5,10,15,20-tetra(4-ethynyl-phenyl)porphyrin]diyne (TEPPD), we designed ORR and OER catalysts by anchoring 3d transition metal into TEPPD (TM@TEPPD, TM = Mn-Zn). Our study indicated that Fe@TEPPD is the best bifunctional catalyst for both ORR and OER. By proposing a proper descriptor, Ni-N3@TEPPD (Ni is only coordinated with three N atoms) is designed and also predicted to be a promising bifunctional catalyst. For Fe@TEPPD, ORR and OER become inactive when the acetylene bond in TEPPD is broken. The surface Pourbaix diagram indicated that on the surface of Fe@TEPPD, ORR and OER can be carried out at the whole pH region due to the high dissolution potential of Fe2+. For Ni-N3@TEPPD, however, the dissolution potential 0.71 V for Ni2+is low. Thus, for Ni-N3@TEPPD, ORR can be carried out only after pH>2.54, while OER is not likely at the whole pH region. This suggested that the conclusions from the free energy changes at URHE=0 and pH=0 could be different when different potentials and pH values are considered. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Oxygen reduction reaction Oxygen evolution reaction Two dimensional materials Bifunctional catalysts Density functional study Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The ever-increasing energy crisis and environmental problems have made people focus more attention on the development of clean and renewable energy sources [1,2]. Fuel cells and water separation systems, as renewable energy storage and conversion technologies, have proven to be promising strategies for mitigating energy crisis and environmental problems. In this aspect, the oxygen-electrocatalytic reactions which occurred in proton exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs), e.g., oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) in the cathode and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) in the anode, are one of the most important electrocatalytic reactions related to energy and environment [3,4]. Exploring the electrocatalysts with high efficiency are the vital factor for enhancing the conversion rate of ORR and OER. Currently, the widely used electrocatalysts are noble metals or their oxides, such as Pt for ORR [5] and IrO2/RuO2 for OER [6]. However, the scarcity and the expensive price of these noble metals limit their largescale commercialization [7]. On the other hand, ORR and OER are multi-electron and multi-proton transfer processes, which are usually kinetically sluggish with high overpotentials [8,9]. Therefore, it is of great importance and challenging task to pursue inexpensive catalysts with high activity. In 2011, the transition metal single atom catalysts (SACs) were proposed and synthesized [10]. The large specific surface area, good stability and flexible tunability made SACs to be outstanding materials in heterogeneous catalytic reaction. Therefore, SACs have been attracted wide attention in the past decade [11,12]. Previous studies indicated that compounds of transition metal and N-doped carbon materials (TM-Nx-C) have good catalytic activity, high selectivity, and excellent durability in electrocatalytic reactions [13–16]. All these characters made TM-Nx-C to be promising materials in oxygen-electrocatalysis. Among them, many non-noble metals, such as Co, Fe, Ni, Zn, Mn, etc. have been a hot topic of research and demonstrated remarkable catalytic activity for ORR and OER process [17–21]. For ORR, the Fe-Nx-C synthesized by high-temperature pyrolysis exhibits high positive half-wave potential of 0.91 V, larger than that of Pt/C (0.82 V) [22]. Co-Nx-C with half-wave potential of 0.81 V is also considered as the potential catalyst [23,24]. For OER, Fe-Nx-C and Co-Nx-C also show high activity with the overpotential of 0.304 and 0.29 V, respectively [25,26]. On the other hand, two dimensional (2D) materials, such as graphene, boron nitride, and graphdiyne, have been employed as the support in oxygen-electrocatalytic reaction due to their excellent physicochemical properties, large surface area and porous features [27–29]. For instance, for Ni-N2C (i.e., nickel coordinated by two N atoms and supported by carbon) [30] and Co-C2N2 [31], they both exhibited favorable ORR and OER bifunctional activity. For Fe-TCNQ, a low overpotential of 0.33 V is obtained for ORR, while Ni-TCNQ is identified as the promising catalyst for OER [32]. Notably, although Zn is generally considered to be not active for oxygen electrocatalysis, Zn-N4-C catalyst with an ultrahigh Zn loading of 9.33 wt % was prepared and found to have good catalytic activity by effectively regulating the high-temperature pyrolysis heating rate [33]. In 2013, porous conducting poly[5,10,15,20-tetra(4-ethynylphenyl)porphyrin]diyne (TEPPD) with large surface area has been fabricated by an in situ cross-coupling reaction on the surface of the copper foil [34]. As a new type of porphyrin-based 2D materials, TEPPD has the advantages of porous features, sp/sp2 hybridization, and a cavity that can accommodate a single metal atom. These features make TEPPD to be one of the most potential supports for the single atom catalysts. Importantly, compared to metalloporphyrin, TEPPD shows a unique linkage via acetylenic bonds, which makes it to form a periodic structure. Thus, the combinations of TEPPD with diverse transition metals could provide an effective method in designing highly efficient catalysts and effective method in designing highly efficient catalysts. A study about the electrocatalytic process of TEPPD is desired to understand the influence of its unique structure on the catalytic activity. In this study, by anchoring 3d transition metals into TEPPD (TM@TEPPD, TM = Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu and Zn), we studied their electrocatalytic performance toward ORR and OER by density functional theory (DFT) method. The free energy changes are investigated to explore the catalytic activity. The surface stability has been evaluated by using the surface Pourbaix diagram, in which the dissolution of metal ions from the substrate is analyzed. We anticipated that our study might provide a new strategy in the search of highly efficient and stable bifunctional catalysts. 2 Computational details The spin polarized DFT calculations were performed by using the Vienna ab initio simulation package (VASP) [35,36] following the projector-augmented wave method [37]. GGA-PBE [38] exchange correlation functional was used to describe electron interactions with the cut-off energy of 450 eV. The convergence criteria were 10−5 eV for energy and 0.05 eV/Å for force. The Gaussian smearing method is used to set the partial occupation of each orbital with a smearing width of 0.10 eV. The van der Waals (vdW) interactions between reactants and substrates were determined by using the semi-empirical scheme proposed by Grimme (DFT-D3) [39]. To accurately describe the strong correlation of 3d orbital, the Hubbard U correction is employed [40,41], while the detailed values for different transition metal elements are determined by the linear-response U approach [42] based on the ab initio calculations (Fig. S1). To avoid the interactions between the periodic images, a 15 Å vacuum space is adopted in the direction perpendicular to the plane. The activity of ORR and OER was studied based on the computational hydrogen electrode (CHE) model proposed by Nørskov et al. [43]. The details can be found in our previous study [44]. ORR proceeds four-electron reaction pathway as follows [45]: (1) step1: *+O2+4(H ++e −) → *OOH+3(H ++e −) (ΔG1 ) (2) step2: *OOH+3(H ++e −) → *O + H2O+2(H ++e −) (ΔG2 ) (3) step3: *O + H2O+2(H ++e −) → *OH+H2O+(H ++e −) (ΔG3 ) (4) step4: *OH+H2O+(H ++e −)→2H2O +* (ΔG4 ) The overpotential of ORR is calculated by the following formula: (5) η ORR = 1.23 − | Δ G | min / e OER is the reverse process of ORR, and the overpotential of OER is defined as: (6) η OER = | Δ G | max / e − 1.23 The crystal orbital Hamilton population (COHP) [44,46] is calculated based on the program of LOBSTER [47]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 The structure and stability of TM@TEPPD The metalloporphyrin structure, as shown in Fig. 1 a, consists of an aromatic 18 e − core with D 4h point group. For TM@TEPPD (Fig. 1b), the H atoms on the meso positions of the metalloporphyrin ligand are replaced by phenyl rings, which connected by acetylene bonds, resulting in a periodic structure. It is important to note that after structural optimization, the phenyl rings are perpendicular to the porphyrin ring due to the steric effect. The example for the optimized geometry of TM@TEPPD is shown in Fig. 1c. On the other hand, it is known that metalloporphyrin is an isolated molecule and has been used as the framework in many of its derivatives, such as TM@TEPPD in this study which is a two dimensional system. In the following, we compared their differences both in geometry and electronic structures. The study showed that compared with metalloporphyrin, the TM-N bond lengths in TM@TEPPD are slightly elongated for TM = Mn, Fe, unchanged for TM = Co, Ni, and Zn, slightly decreased for TM = Cu (Fig. S3). For the electronic structure, the calculated density of states showed very large difference, in particular the distribution of transition metal 3d orbitals (Fig. S4). For TM = Mn, Fe, Co, the d band center moves towards to the Fermi energy level in TM@TEPPD compared with the corresponding metalloporphyrin. For example, the d band center is at −0.07 eV for Mn-porphyrin, while it is 1.00 eV for Mn@TEPPD (Fig. S4). For TM = Ni, Cu, Zn, opposite d band center shift is observed, i.e., d band center moves away from the Fermi energy level in TM@TEPPD compared with the corresponding metalloporphyrin. This suggests that the modified metalloporphyrin TM@TEPPD would have quite different properties compared with isolated metalloporphyrin. Stability is crucial in catalyst design. Therefore, the binding energy and cohesive energy have been calculated to estimate the stability of TM@TEPPD (Fig. 1d, details in Table S1). The binding energy (ΔEb) is calculated by the formula of ΔEb = Emetal/sub – Emetal - Esub, where the Emetal/sub is the total energy of TM@TEPPD, while Emetal and Esub are the energies of single metal atom and TEPPD, respectively. The cohesive energy (ΔEcoh) is obtained by the formula of ΔEcoh = (Ebulk – nEmetal)/n, where the Ebulk is the energy of the bulk metal and n is the number of metal atoms in the bulk phase. As seen in Fig. 1d, the more negative ΔEb relative to ΔEcoh suggests that the embedded metal atoms Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, and Zn can exist stably in the framework, indicating that they are stable. 3.2 Reaction mechanism and catalytic activity For TM@TEPPD (TM=Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu and Zn), the TM-N4 moiety is the activity center for ORR and OER [48,49].The widely used 4e− mechanism is as follows: O2 ↔ *OOH ↔ *O ↔ *OH ↔ H2O [50–52]. The optimized geometries and intermediate adsorption structures are shown in Fig. S2. Among the investigated catalysts, the chemisorption of *OOH is not obtained for Cu@TEPPD due to the fact that the bond distance between Cu and OOH is long (2.45 Å, Fig. S2) and the *OOH adsorption energy is positive (0.46 eV), implying that Cu@TEPPD is not active enough to make the reduction of O2 to generate *OOH. Hence, in the following discussion, Cu@TEPPD is not considered. For the other TM@TEPPD, the calculated the free energy changes (∆G) for the elementary reactions are summarized in Table S2 and S3, while the free energy profiles are shown in Fig. 2 a and 2b. For free energy profiles (Fig. 2a), the downhill for each protonation process is observed on TM@TEPPD for ORR at U = 0 V, except for Zn@TEPPD and Co@TEPPD (slightly uphill at O2 →*OOH). Since the minimum free energy change (|∆G|min) of protonation step determines the ORR activity, the protonation step of *OH → H2O (∆G4= −0.56 eV) is the potential determining step (PDS) for Mn@TEPPD, while it is O2 → *OOH for TM=Fe and Ni. The calculated overpotential for TM@TEPPD (TM = Mn, Fe and Ni) are 0.67, 0.41 and 1.21 V, respectively. Thus, Fe@TEPPD shows the best ORR activity, which is comparable to the commercial Pt/C (0.45 V) [53]. In addition to the 4e− pathway as discussed above, we also studied the 2e− pathway via intermediate H2O2. The calculated adsorption energy indicated that H2O2 adsorbs strongly on TM@TEPPD with the adsorption energies of −1.07 eV for TM=Mn, −0.84 eV for TM=Fe, −1.27 eV for TM=Co, −1.04 eV for TM=Ni and −1.24 eV for TM=Zn. This implied that H2O2 is not the final product and the ORR reaction would continue to complete the reaction. On the other hand, from the calculated free energies (Fig. S5), we also noted that for TM=Mn and Fe, *O is more favorable than *H2O2, suggesting that *O would be the main intermediate on the catalyst surface. For TM=Co and Zn, since the first step O2 → *OOH is endothermic, this made them to be inactive for ORR in both 2e− and 4e− processes. For TM=Ni, although *H2O2 showed lower free energy than *O, the PDS is the same, i.e., O2 → *OOH. Thus, in this study, we would focus on the 4e− pathway. For OER, the activity is determined by the maximum |∆G|max. For TM@TEPPD (TM= Mn-Ni and Zn), the PDS are all *OH→*O (Fig. 2b). The calculated overpotentials for TM@TEPPD (TM = Fe, Mn, Ni, Co, and Zn) are 0.69, 0.93, 1.03, 0.69, and 1.23 V, respectively, in which Fe@TEPPD and Co@TEPPD have the best OER performance. 3.3 The activity trend For intermediate adsorption structures on TM@TEPPD, all the species would interact with TM atom through oxygen atom. Such similar interaction will bring the similar change trend for adsorption free energy of the intermediates, i.e., a linear relationship [32,44,54,55]. Thus, the scaling relationship between the adsorption free energy of the intermediates has been investigated to explore the reaction trend and to find a proper descriptor. Based on the values of ∆G*OH, ∆G*O and ∆G*OOH (Table S4), the obvious scaling relationship among ∆G*OH, ∆G*O and ∆G*OOH can be found (Fig. 3 a), i.e., ∆G*OOH = 0.69∆G*OH +3.49 (R2=0.79) and ∆G*O = 1.12∆G*OH +1.92 (R2=0.94). It is seen that the slope of ∆G*O vs ∆G*OH is close to unity, i.e., 1.12. This suggests that the *O → *OH would have similar free energy changes (≈1.92 eV), which is less sensitive to the type of TM species. Therefore, the activity is mainly determined by the energies of *OOH and *OH. On the other hand, ∆G*OOH is linearly related to ∆G*OH (Fig. 3a). This indicates that the reaction activity of OER and ORR could be described by ∆G*OH. Previous studies on the electronic structure analysis also indicated that the adsorbed *OH plays an important role in understanding the catalytic mechanism of ORR/OER [56–58]. Since the electrode potentials can be used to describe the activity of ORR and OER [59–61], the equilibrium potential UL for each protonation step can be expressed by ∆G*OH (see Supporting Information for details). Based on the relationship, the change among the equilibrium potentials (UL) and ∆G*OH can be constructed (Fig. 3b), which can be employed to estimate the activity trend of OER/ORR. For ORR, since the minimum |∆Gx| determines the activity, the volcano plot can be built by U1 and U4, and the intersection is appeared at ∆G*OH = 0.85 eV. This means that TM@TEPPD with ∆G*OH close to 0.85 eV would have the best activity for ORR, while those with weak ∆G*OH (>0.85 eV) or strong ∆G*OH (<0.85 eV) would have less catalytic activity. Thus, the best ORR catalyst is Fe@TEPPD. However, for the OER, there is not a distinct volcano relationship but rather an activity range (∼ 0.56 - 2.26 eV for ∆G*OH in Fig. S6). This situation is similar to the Ni-substitution on IrO2 surface for OER in pervious theoretical study [62]. Nonetheless, it can still be found that Fe@TEPPD and Co@TEPPD has the best activity for OER (η = 0.69 V). Overall, based on the above results, Fe@TEPPD is the potential bifunctional catalyst for both ORR and OER. 3.4 The physical insights and activity descriptor Based on the above discussion, it is seen that ∆G*OH can be employed as a descriptor for ORR and OER activity. However, since ∆G*OH has to be obtained by complex quantum chemical calculations, more practical or intuitive descriptor could be more interesting to the researchers, particularly to the experimentalists. Toward this purpose, the partial density of states (PDOS) and projected crystal orbital Hamilton population (pCOHP) for *OH adsorbed on TM@TEPPD are analyzed first (Fig. S7). For PDOS, the significant hybridization between the TM-3d orbitals and O-2p orbitals is found, suggesting that the two atomic orbitals would contribute more to *OH adsorption. On the other hand, the integral value of COHP (ICOHP) of TM-O is employed to estimate the TM-O bond strength, i.e., the more negative the ICOHP, the stronger the TM-OH interaction. The ICOHP values for TM@TEPPD (TM=Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Zn) are −1.77, −1.64, −1.26, −0.49 and −0.60. It is found that the Fe@TEPPD and Co@TEPPD show stronger adsorption strength for *OH (Fig. 3c). Furthermore, the ICOHP of TM-O is consistent with the adsorption free energy of *OH (∆G*OH), and a good linear relationship can be observed in Fig. 3c. This indicates that TM-O bond strength can be employed to describe ∆G*OH. In other words, TM-O bond strength could be related to ORR and OER activity. To further analyze the origin of TM-O bond strength, the compositions of atomic orbital for TM-O bonding state are calculated and shown in Table 1 . It is seen that the hybrid orbitals of 4s-2s and 3dz 2 −2p have more contributions compared with the other composition, indicating that 4s and 3dz 2 orbitals in transition metal play a dominant role in *OH adsorption. This can be further confirmed by the example of *OH adsorption on Fe@TEPPD (Fig. 4 a). In addition, it is noted that TM-O bonds with higher ratio of δ3dz 2 –2p show more negative ICOHP (−1.77, −1.64 and −1.26 for Mn@TEPPD, Fe@TEPPD, and Co@TEPPD, respectively), while those with higher ratio of δ4s-2s show less negative ICOHP (−0.49 and −0.60 for Ni@TEPPD and Zn@TEPPD). This suggests that 4s/3dz 2 orbital of TM would have less/more contribution to the TM-O bond strength. Unfortunately, there is no linear trend for the TM-O bond strength and δ4s-2s /δ3dz 2 –2p (Fig. 4b). However, when we check the electron occupation numbers of the 3d and 4s orbitals in TM@TEPPD (TM = Mn-Ni, and Zn) with adsorbed *OH, we found that the electron occupation numbers of 3d orbitals are about 3.67, 4.89, 5.02, 4.93, and 3.36 times higher than those of the 4s orbitals, while the average ratio of 3d:4 s is about 4.37 (Table S5). Thus, we propose an expression θ, θ=4.37×δ4s-2s – δ3dz 2 –2p (R2=0.96), which show a linear relationship with ICOHP (Fig. 4c). The coefficient for δ4s-2s is 4.37 times larger than that for δ3dz 2 –2p, suggesting that 3d orbital would show more influence for *OH adsorption compared to s orbital. This is in agreement with the d band center theory proposed by Hammer and Nørskov [63–65], which indicates that the d orbital in transition metals would be the key to the adsorption of intermediate species. Motivated by this result, the relationship between d band center (ɛd, the average values of spin-up and -down 3d orbital channels) of TM and ∆G*OH is explored (Fig. 4d). For Zn@TEPPD, since its 3d orbital is fully filled and contributes less to the *OH adsorption (Fig. S7 and Table 1), it is not included in Fig. 4d. In Fig. 4d, it is seen that the d band center (εd) shows a good linear relationship with ∆G*OH, i.e., the closer of ɛd to the Fermi level, the stronger the adsorption of *OH. This is consistent with the d band center theory [66]. Based on the above results, the descriptors involving orbital hybridization for bonding (θ) or d band center (ɛd), can effectively estimate adsorption strength of OH intermediate and predict the reaction activities. However, the above descriptors must be obtained through the detailed calculation based on the constructed structure. Thus, it is powerless to employ such descriptors to predict unknown catalyst. Based on the information of atomic orbital in θ and ɛd, we realize that the activity of the catalyst is closely related to the adsorption strength and the number of electrons in the d orbitals of the metal. In addition, the coordination environment is also a major factor influencing catalytic performance. Thus, we propose a descriptor Φ, i.e., Φ=Nc×Nd×r, in which Nc is the coordination number of the transition metal, Nd is the electron numbers in the 3d orbital, and r is the atomic radius of the transition metal. Interestingly, we found that Φ has a good linear relationship with ∆G*OH, i.e., ∆G*OH = 0.12Φ - 2.66 (R2=0.99) (Fig. 5 a), indicating that the descriptor Φ can be used to calculate ∆G*OH and predict the catalytic activity of TM@TEPPD. Furthermore, compared to θ, Φ is more concise and the three parameters involved in Φ can be directly obtained without complex computation. Thus Φ is more applicable and universal as a predictive descriptor, and its results (R2=0.99, Fig. 5a) are more accurate than θ (R2=0.96, Fig. 4c) and comparable with ɛd (R2=0.99, Fig. 4d).” Furthermore, according to the ligand field theory, the interaction between nitrogen and metals in the TM-Nx-C structure can significantly alter the energy levels of the d orbitals of the metal atoms, which can affect the catalytic activity. And changing the ligand environment is an effective means to change the interaction between M and N [67,68]. Based on the descriptor Φ, we further explored the influence of coordination number in TM@TEPPD for ORR and OER activity. For TM@TEPPD, the maximum coordination number for transition metal is 4 (Fig. 1b). This means that new structures with TM-N3 and TM-N2 moiety can be designed. From the linear relationship between Φ and ∆G*OH, higher Φ would give a weaker ∆G*OH, and at ∆G*OH = 0.85 eV, ORR and OER activity would be the best. Thus, when Nc = 3, structure with Ni-N3 moiety (Fig. S2, denoted as Ni-N3@TEPPD in the following) has the best ORR and OER activity (Fig. 5a). However, for Nc = 2, the predicted activity is low, indicating that structures with TM-N2 moiety are not good catalysts for ORR and OER (Fig. 5a). Since the structure with Ni-N3 moiety has the best catalytic activity as predicted by the proposed descriptor (Ni-N3-Φ, Fig. 5a), to further verify our prediction, we have optimized the model structure Ni-N3@TEPPD as shown in Fig. S2. Our study showed that the calculated adsorption free energy of *OH is closer to 0.85 eV (TM-N3 in Fig. 5b), supporting the predicted result by the descriptor. For Ni-N3@TEPPD from the optimized model structure, the calculated overpotentials are 0.37 V for ORR and 0.63 V for OER, much better than Ni@TEPPD (Fig. 5c). These values are comparable to Fe@TEPPD (0.41 and 0.69 V). This means that Ni-N3@TEPPD is also a good ORR and OER bifunctional catalyst. 3.5 The impact of acetylene bond on catalytic activity From Fig. 1b, we noted that there are four acetylene bonds (-CC-) in each unit cell. To investigate its influence on catalytic activity, we artificially broken the -CC- bond to form -CHCH- by adding two hydrogen atoms for each bond. Thus, for each unit cell, totally eight hydrogen atoms are added, and we denote the new structure as Ni-N3@TEPPD-8H and Fe@TEPPD-8H. We are interested to these two catalysts because Ni-N3@TEPPD and Fe@TEPPD have the best catalytic activity from the above study. For Ni-N3@TEPPD-8H and Fe@TEPPD-8H, the optimized geometries without and with adsorbed intermediates are shown in Fig. S2, and the calculated free energy changes are given in Fig. 6 a. It is seen from Fig. 6a that although the downhill for the protonation process is observed for these catalysts, they show different catalytic activities. For Ni-N3@TEPPD-8H, although PDS is the same as Ni-N3@TEPPD, i.e., *OH→H2O, the calculated overpotentials are different. For ORR, it is 0.59 V for Ni-N3@TEPPD-8H, higher than 0.37 V for Ni-N3@TEPPD, showing lower ORR activity for the former. For OER, the activity of Ni-N3@TEPPD-8H is slightly improved with overpotential 0.59 V, lower than 0.63 V in Ni-N3@TEPPD. In contrast, Fe@TEPPD-8H shows different PDS compared with Fe@TEPPD, i.e., *OH→H2O vs *OOH→*O. In addition, the catalytic activity of Fe@TEPPD-8H is much poor compared with Fe@TEPPD for both ORR and OER. The calculated overpotentials are 0.41 V (ORR) and 0.69 V (OER) for Fe@TEPPD, while they are 1.22 V (ORR) and 1.29 V (OER) for Fe@TEPPD-8H. This means that Fe@TEPPD-8H has no catalytic activity. The above results indicated that the activity of Fe@TEPPD is more sensitive to the change of the acetylene bond than Ni-N3@TEPPD. To get insight into the influence of acetylene bonds on activity, the PDOS for the both catalysts are shown in Fig. 6b and c. For Ni-N3@TEPPD-8H, it is seen that the energy band of Ni 3d orbitals is closer to the Fermi level and more narrow compared with Ni-N3@TEPPD (Fig. 6b). Furthermore, there is an obvious shift for the antibonding orbitals to the higher energy level. This might be the reason that the adsorption strength of intermediate can be tuned in Ni-N3@TEPPD-8H. In addition, the PDOS also showed that Ni-N3@TEPPD and Ni-N3@TEPPD-8H are metallic. For Fe@TEPPD-8H (Fig. 6c), its semiconducting behavior might be the reason for the low catalytic activity. 3.6 Surface Pourbaix diagrams To determine the most stable surface and surface stability, we would discuss the surface Pourbaix diagram[66] of Ni-N3@TEPPD and Fe@TEPPD. In this diagram, we calculate the free energy of a given surface structure at different potentials and pH values as shown in Eq. (7). (7) Δ G = Δ G [ U = 0 , pH = 0 ] − − n e U SHE − kT ln 10 pH At a given set of potential and pH, the surface structure with the lowest free energy determines the stable form of the surface. Since this calculation gives three dimensional diagram, we first study the dependence with the potential at pH = 0. In this case, at given potential, the lowest line determines the most stable surface with the lowest free energy. Each intermediate species along the catalytic path on the catalytic surface can be described by a straight line, in which the negative slope corresponds to the transferred electron number n (n = 0 for clean substrate surface, n = 1 for *OH adsorbed surface, n = 2 for *O adsorbed surface, n = 3 for *OOH adsorbed surface, n = 4 for molecular oxygen). In addition, Since OER and ORR are reversible process involving the same intermediate species, both reactions can be studied in the same diagram as shown in Fig. 7 . From the potential and free energy curves at pH=0 (Fig. 7a and 7b), it can be observed that for both catalysts, the lowest line of free energy is composed by three most stable phases, i.e., SUB (clean substrate surface), surface adsorbed with *OH, and free O2 molecule. For Fe@TEPPD, the SUB is the most stable at URHE of 0 ∼ 0.88 V, *OH is the most stable at URHE of 0.88 ∼1.35 V, and molecular O2 at URHE > 1.35 V. Similar results are obtained for Ni-N3@TEPPD. Meanwhile, we also noted that surfaces adsorbed with *O and *OOH are never the most stable species at any potentials. In addition, URHE > 1.23 V is also not feasible because it exceeds the equilibrium potential for ORR. Next, we study the pH range from 0 to 14, which is defined as follows: (8) U RHE = U pH = 0 − kT ln 10 pH Based on Eq. (8), the surface Pourbaix diagram was constructed for T = 298 K (Fig. 7c and 7d). In this diagram, the most stable surface is obtained by considering varying potential and pH values, in which the dissolution of the metal atom from the substrate is the focus of this study. For the dissolution of the metal ions, we have: (9) E 0 ( T M z + / TM @ TEPPD ) = E TEPPD + E TM − − E TM @ TEPPD + α where ETEPPD, ETM and ETM@TEPPD are the energies of TM@TEPPD, single metal atom, and pure TEPPD, respectively. α is the standard Gibbs free energy and it is −0.82 eV for Fe2+ atom and −0.47 eV for Ni2+. Since the metal dissolution Eq. (8) has no proton transfer involved, it is independent of pH and only potential dependent through the following equation: (10) E = E 0 ( T M z + / TM @ TEPPD ) + ( 0.059 V / z ) · log a ( M z + ) − − z U RHE Herein, we used a(Mz+) = 10−8 mol dm−3. Then, we obtain E(Fe2+/Fe@TEPPD) =4.27–2 U and E (Ni2+/Ni-N3@TEPPD) =1.41–2URHE. From the two formula, we can see that Fe atom would be dissolved as Fe2+ at URHE of 2.13 V (Fig. 7c), which is much higher than the working potentials of ORR and OER. This suggested that Fe atom is stable in TEPPD during the catalytic process. On the other hand, from Fig. 7c for Fe@TEPPD, we also noted that the clean substrate surface is the most stable, and with the increase of pH values, the URHE changes from 0.88 V at pH=0 to 0.054 V at pH=14. Since the working potentials for ORR lies on this stable region, it indicated that ORR process can proceed on the clean substrate surface at all pH values. For OER, the working potential line is below the dissolution potential, suggesting that OER can also be carried out on the catalyst surface. As for Ni atoms (Fig. 7d), the dissolution potential is 0.71 V for Ni-N3@TEPPD, implying that Ni atom would be dissolved from the substrate after URHE is larger than 0.71 V. Therefore, in order to maintain the stability of the catalyst, the operating potential should be less than 0.71 V. Moreover, the clean substrate surface is also the most stable for Ni-N3@TEPPD. From Fig. 7d, we also noted that at pH values of 0∼2.54, the working potential of Ni-N3@TEPPD locates in the dissolution region of Ni2+, showing unstable clean substrate structure. After pH> 2.54, ORR can proceed properly. For OER, the working potential is located in the dissolution region of Ni2+, suggesting that Ni-N3@TEPPD is not a suitable OER catalyst. 4 Conclusions In this study, we conducted a theoretical study on the transition metal anchored poly[5,10,15,20-tetra(4-ethynyl-phenyl)porphyrin]diyne (TM@TEPPD, TM = Mn-Zn) as the potential ORR and OER bifunctional catalyst. From the DFT calculations, we found that Fe@TEPPD is a promising ORR and OER bifunctional catalyst with the overpotentials of 0.41 and 0.69 V. Mn@TEPPD is only good for ORR (overpotential 0.67 V), while Co@TEPPD for OER (overpotential 0.69 V). By proposing a descriptor Φ, i.e., Φ=Nc×Nd×r, in which Nc is the coordination number of the transition metal, Nd is electron numbers in the 3d orbital, and r is the atomic radius of the transition metal, we made further prediction by changing the coordination number. Our study showed that when the coordination number decreases from 4 to 3, Ni-N3@TEPPD is found to be the promising ORR and OER bifunctional catalyst with the overpotentials of 0.37 and 0.63 V. On the other hand, for Fe@TEPPD, ORR and OER become inactive when the acetylene bond in TEPPD is broken. For Ni-N3@TEPPD, after the broken of acetylene bond, ORR activity is reduced, while OER is improved slightly. The stability study by using the surface Pourbaix diagram indicated that for Fe@TEPPD, the dissolution of Fe2+ occurs at potentials larger than 2.13 V, which means that ORR and OER can be carried out at the whole pH region. For Ni-N3@TEPPD, the dissolution potential of Ni2+ is 0.71 V. This made ORR occurring only at pH > 2.54, while OER is not likely at the whole pH region. This result reminds us that the conclusions from the free energy changes at URHE=0 and pH=0 could be different after the varying potentials and pH values are considered. We expect that our work might provide useful ideas for the future experimental study. coredata.dc:description: Searching for highly active oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) catalysts is a challenging task in the development of clean energy devices. Herein, by using the poly[5,10,15,20-tetra(4-ethynyl-phenyl)porphyrin]diyne (TEPPD), we designed ORR and OER catalysts by anchoring 3d transition metal into TEPPD (TM@TEPPD, TM = Mn-Zn). Our study indicated that Fe@TEPPD is the best bifunctional catalyst for both ORR and OER. By proposing a proper descriptor, Ni-N3@TEPPD (Ni is only coordinated with three N atoms) is designed and also predicted to be a promising bifunctional catalyst. For Fe@TEPPD, ORR and OER become inactive when the acetylene bond in TEPPD is broken. The surface Pourbaix diagram indicated that on the surface of Fe@TEPPD, ORR and OER can be carried out at the whole pH region due to the high dissolution potential of Fe2+. For Ni-N3@TEPPD, however, the dissolution potential 0.71 V for Ni2+is low. Thus, for Ni-N3@TEPPD, ORR can be carried out only after pH>2.54, while OER is not likely at the whole pH region. This suggested that the conclusions from the free energy changes at URHE=0 and pH=0 could be different when different potentials and pH values are considered.
coredata.dc:title: Theoretical insights on 3D transition metal anchored poly[5,10,15,20-tetra(4-ethynylphenyl)porphyrin]diyne as highly efficient bifunctional catalyst toward ORR and OER
